text:
> Can we make the same statement about the Splice Wallet UI: "_External parties are supported in the API, but not in the Splice Wallet UI"?_
Yes, but with some caveats (e.g. I don't think the Wallet automation works with external parties. Moreover, token standard CC transfer are also subject to a short signing window (the issue I mentioned above). I think it's better to clarify in <#C08FQRCRFUN|gsf-global-synchronizer-appdev>

>  And so, Splice Wallet UI and Utility UI only support 'Local Parties', right ?
Yes

Did you by any chance restore your TestNet node after an inactivity period longer than 30 days?

thanks Tony.

Did you by any chance restore your TestNet node after an inactivity period longer than 30 days?

text: <@U06GRUXKVHB> do you know?

What we think is happening
• our participant node has a `UserService` contract for that party
• your node went off for some time and was restored with an empty ACS but using the same keys (i.e. your ledger doesn't contain the `UserService` contract we had initially established)
• any new request for `UserService` gets rejected by us, because according to our ledger you already have one
• my attempt to revoke the existing `UserService` fails because your participant (restored with empty ACS) rejects the transaction as it doesn't know the contract)

text: At least this didn’t happen on mainnet :smile:

So, the only option to fix this is to perform a set of rather complex "repair commands" where
• we export the relevant portions of our ACS and send them over
• you import them into your participant node via the Canton console
I suggest to not go through this process for the `TestNet` node. Using a new party or spinning up a fresh node is to be preferred, as data retention is not an issue here.

For `MainNet`, the recommendation is to recover the participant node from a backup, rather than recovering from keys with an empty ACS.

Should the latter be unavoidable, we would need to go through repair commands.

> Just on a remote VM. 
Ah! I’m no expert on deploying Docker Compose networks. However, I would _expect_ you would need to edit your `nginx.conf` to reflect the hosted names. That is, if I understand what <https://nginx.org/en/docs/http/server_names.html|server_name> means. The `nginx.conf` you sent maps calls for `wallet.localhost`, `ans.localhost`, `validator.localhost`,  `utility.localhost`, etc. to containers running within the Docker Compose network.

I’m guessing you are navigating to something like `<https://utility.myaccount.myhostingservice.com>` and since that server name is not found in the `nginx.conf` file, it is defaulting to the wallet.

text: <@U08JYBDSK0V> To make sure we're clear: You can use the Splice Wallet UI to transfer to, and receive from, an external party, but the Splice wallet UI does not yet allow you to log in as an external party or display the balance and transactions of an external party.

text: Is there an issue impacting the operator in mainnet?   The statuses in the utility all show the last billing as successful, but the last billed timestamps for our credentials are older than would be expected (some as old as 8/4)  and our commercial agreement has a last billed about 2 hrs ago

elements.text: Is there an issue impacting the operator in mainnet?   The statuses in the utility all show the last billing as successful, but the last billed timestamps for our credentials are older than would be expected (some as old as 8/4)  and our commercial agreement has a last billed about 2 hrs ago

text:
Hi Matt, thanks for raising this.

It was indeed an issuer on our side, where tasks were suspended due to a validator upgrade during our maintenance window and we omitted the step necessary to restart them.

It should now be good, sorry for the inconvenience.

elements.text:
Hi Matt, thanks for raising this.

It was indeed an issuer on our side, where tasks were suspended due to a validator upgrade during our maintenance window and we omitted the step necessary to restart them.

It should now be good, sorry for the inconvenience.
